title: Russia face Tokyo Olympics ban over ‘inconsistent’ Moscow lab data
text:
• Wada gives Russia three weeks to explain alleged irregularities • Russia’s appearance at World Athletics Championships in doubt

The World Anti-Doping Agency has given Russia three weeks to explain alleged irregularities in laboratory data retrieved from Moscow.

Wada said it would fast-track a “formal compliance procedure” to look into the allegations at a meeting of its executive committee in Tokyo. If substantiated, the results could trigger a fresh ban on Russian athletes at next year’s Tokyo Olympics.

In a statement Wada said that further investigation into the “inconsistencies” in the laboratory data obtained in January had “led Wada to open a formal compliance procedure against Russia”.

The statement added: “Ensuring the authenticity of the Moscow Laboratory Information Management System (LIMS) and underlying raw data was one of the critical conditions imposed by the ExCo for Rusada to maintain its compliance with the code when the ExCo decided to reinstate Rusada as code-compliant in September 2018.“

The developments could jeopardise Russian hopes of competing at this month’s World Athletics Championships in Qatar, having been banned by the sport’s governing body since 2015.

Athletics’ world governing body the IAAF, which upheld its ban on Russia for the 11th time in June, is set to reconsider the sanction once more prior to the start of the Championships.

Wada said it had given Russia’s anti-doping agency, Rusada, three weeks to provide its comments on the “inconsistencies”, and to provide answers to a list of specific questions.

The statement added: “Once that response has been received and analysed, Wada I&I [Intelligence and Investigations Department] and the independent forensic experts will report back to the CRC [Compliance Review Committee], so that the CRC is in a position to decide whether to bring a formal recommendation to the ExCo.

“No fixed timeline can be set for this, as due process must be respected, but the ExCo was assured that WADA is pursuing the matter robustly and as quickly as practicable.”
